document.docTitle: Syneches striatus Menezes & Ale-Rocha, 2016, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Amazonian species of Syneches Walker (Diptera, Hybotidae, Hybotinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Amazonian species of Syneches Walker (Diptera, Hybotidae, Hybotinae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis . Antenna with scape and pedicel dark brown; postpedicel long, ovate, pale yellow, 1 / 3 longer than length of scape and pedicel combined. Scutum light brown except anterior region at acrostichal area, intra-alar region, narrow longitudinal stripe at prescutellar disc and anterior half of postpronotal lobe brown; pleura pale brown, except anepisternum, anterior half of katepisternum, anepimeron and laterotergite, brown; scutellum with three pairs of setae, apical pair absent. Hind femur slightly enlarged; hind femur brown with 1 preapical yellow ring, fore and mid femora yellow with basal, median and preapical brown rings, fore and hind tibia yellow with 1 sub-basal and 1 median or preapical brown ring; wing sub-hyaline, pterostigma large, rectangular, brownish stain at apex of Sc and R 2 + 3 , tenuous brown infuscation on transverse veins.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 80–86 .
Syneches striatus
sp. nov.
(paratype). Male terminalia: 80 , epandrium, cerci and hypoproct (dorsal view); 81 , hypandrium, postgonite and phallus (ventral view); 82 , left epandrial lamella (lateral view); 83 , tergite 8; 84 , sternite 8. Female terminalia: 85 , ventral view; 86 , dorsal view. Scale = 0.2 mm.

1 ° 5 ′N-
69 ° 51 ′W
/
06.iv- 15 .v. 1993
, J. Vidal / Holótipo,
Syneches striatus , Menezes & Ale-Rocha
(red label). Specimen in good conditions.

Comments . The new species is easily distinguished from congeners by having brown rings on the legs, which gives a striped appearance to the specimen, and postpedicel long when compared with the other species (it is comparatively smaller than in
S. longiflagellatus ,
which has very long postpedicel, 3.5 times longer than scape and pedicel together).

Etymology . From the Latin
striatus
= streak, band, in reference to the coloration of the legs, yellow with brown rings.
